evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

Not explained by any other root

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The statements from crew members accurately reflect their communication and coordination during the event.
Lack of warnings or verbal alerts implies a breakdown in communication.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and warnings among crew members preventing or addressing the TRP overrun.
If the crew had explicit procedures that were followed correctly without miscommunication.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows multiple crew members failed to communicate or warn each other about the aircraft passing the TRP, indicating a communication/coordination breakdown during the pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit transcript of interphone or verbal communications; assumptions about intent and awareness are inferred from statements.

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal is currently present and impacting system operations.

defeaters: Evidence showing mechanical or control system malfunction impacting operations
Reports or data indicating system faults or failures during the event
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates a mechanical or control failure was present or impacting system operations; all evidence describes human actions and situational details without mention of mechanical/control failure.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, indicating relevant causal factors.

assumptions: The described crew roles and interactions reflect the main communication pathways relevant to the breakdown
The absence of warnings or signals is indicative of communication failure rather than deliberate non-action
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew during the event
If the crew had explicit warnings or signals that were ignored
If the TRP size or environment was not a factor in communication issues

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12, H13) directly describes communication and coordination issues among the crew during pushback, including insufficient visual signals, assumptions made by crew members, and lack of warnings, aligning with key features of communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about the extent to which communication failures versus other factors (e.g., procedural or environmental) contributed to the event.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS with registration 9H-QAA during the historical prefinal inspection phase (12-25).

defeaters: If evidence showed a marking or environmental deficiency present and observable during the prefinal inspection phase on the specified aircraft.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history indicates the presence or observability of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the prefinal inspection phase (12-25). The evidence focuses on the pushback operation and collision but does not mention any deficiency in environment or markings.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal data.

defeaters: If the historical timeline data did not explicitly document the procedural deviation or was not accessible in the specified dataset.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against common defeaters and inconsistencies within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal context.

assumptions: The lack of warnings or interventions implies procedural weaknesses
The small TRP size contributes to difficulty in adherence to procedure
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and intervention by the wingman or headset operator preventing the deviation
If the TRP was clearly marked and easily visible to all involved
If the tug instructor had clear, reliable methods to stop the pushback promptly

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that the procedural deviation led to the aircraft moving beyond the TRP and hitting the blast fence (H4), with no effective warnings or interventions from the wingman or headset operator (H8, H10, H12). The small size of the TRP (H13) and lack of mandatory marshalling wands suggest potential for confusion or error. This indicates the procedural deviation was not robust against common defeaters such as lack of communication or situational awareness.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity about the exact communication protocols and whether other unseen factors contributed to the deviation

defeaters: If the TRP markings were found to be inconsistent with Boeing 737-8AS specifications or if the clearance was insufficient for this aircraft type, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

H13 supports this by noting the TRP size, confirming marking characteristics.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit documentation of the full criteria or key features for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA TRP markings is provided, so alignment is inferred from described clearance and location.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is supported by evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal and is resistant to alternative explanations or defeaters.

assumptions: The statements from crew members are accurate and complete; no other communications or factors influenced the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed active communication or warnings were given and ignored, or if the crew had clear reasons for their actions that justified the pushback beyond the TRP.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) directly shows that communication and coordination among the crew broke down, as key crew members did not warn or question the instructor despite the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast fence, indicating resistance to alternative explanations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in crew intentions and possible unreported communications; lack of explicit statements about alternative explanations.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal inspection.

assumptions: The TRP marking and visual signals are the primary environmental/marking deficiency relevant to the pushback operation
The statements from personnel accurately reflect the situational awareness and communication during the event
defeaters: If there were documented procedures or additional markings/signals that were clearly visible and consistently used to prevent passing the TRP
If communication protocols ensured immediate warnings from wingman or headset operator upon approaching the TRP
If the TRP was physically more prominent or had fail-safe mechanisms to stop the tug

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows the TRP marking was small and visual signals for stopping the tug were insufficient or not always noticed (H7, H8, H13). The tug instructor and other personnel did not provide or receive effective warnings before the collision (H8, H12), indicating the identification of the environmental or marking deficiency was not robust against exceptions or defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in how well the TRP marking and associated signals were designed and used; lack of direct evidence on robustness of identification methods

The evidence focuses on the pushback operation and collision but does not mention any deficiency in environment or markings.

assumptions: The TRP marking and visual signals are the primary environmental/marking deficiency relevant to the pushback operation
The statements from personnel accurately reflect the situational awareness and communication during the event
defeaters: If there were documented procedures or additional markings/signals that were clearly visible and consistently used to prevent passing the TRP
If communication protocols ensured immediate warnings from wingman or headset operator upon approaching the TRP
If the TRP was physically more prominent or had fail-safe mechanisms to stop the tug
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows the TRP marking was small and visual signals for stopping the tug were insufficient or not always noticed (H7, H8, H13). The tug instructor and other personnel did not provide or receive effective warnings before the collision (H8, H12), indicating the identification of the environmental or marking deficiency was not robust against exceptions or defeaters.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in how well the TRP marking and associated signals were designed and used; lack of direct evidence on robustness of identification methods

assumptions: The TRP described in H7 and H13 corresponds to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection.
defeaters: If the TRP markings were found to be inconsistent with Boeing 737-8AS specifications or if the clearance was insufficient for this aircraft type, this would change the assessment.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 directly describes the TRP location and clearance relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, indicating the environmental marking (TRP) aligns with key features and criteria for the aircraft during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection. H13 supports this by noting the TRP size, confirming marking characteristics.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: No explicit documentation of the full criteria or key features for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA TRP markings is provided, so alignment is inferred from described clearance and location.

defeaters: Evidence showing mechanical or control system malfunction impacting operations
Reports or data indicating system faults or failures during the event
availability.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates a mechanical or control failure was present or impacting system operations; all evidence describes human actions and situational details without mention of mechanical/control failure.

assumptions: Personnel would have raised concerns if alternative explanations were plausible
The absence of warnings or objections implies acceptance of the instructor's control as valid
defeaters: If evidence showed personnel actively questioned or contradicted the instructor's control actions
If alternative causes for the pushback past the TRP were identified and supported by evidence
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: The evidence indicates that the mechanical/control failure was not challenged by the involved personnel, who assumed the instructor's actions were correct and did not provide warnings (H8, H10, H12). This suggests resistance to common defeaters and alternative explanations, supporting the claim's validity.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: lack of direct evidence explicitly ruling out alternative explanations or defeaters

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control failure modes or symptoms matching the incident
Technical analysis or inspection reports indicating mechanical/control failure
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items (H1-H13) describes or supports a mechanical or control failure or matches expected failure modes and symptoms related to such a failure.
